clusters.title: Ultra-processed food is global health threat, experts warn
clusters.neutral_headline: Ultra-processed food is global health threat, experts warn

items.title: Ultra-processed food is global health threat, experts warn
items.standfirst: It is increasing our risk of a range of chronic diseases, including obesity and depression, a major review says.
items.content: It is increasing our risk of a range of chronic diseases, including obesity and depression, a major review says.

items.title: Ultra-processed food linked to harm in every major human organ, study finds
items.standfirst: World’s largest scientific review warns consumption of UPFs poses seismic threat to global health and wellbeingUltra-processed food (UPF) is linked to harm in every major organ system of the human body and poses a seismic threat to global health, according to the world’s largest review.UPF is also rapidly displacing fresh food in the diets of children and adults on every continent, and is associated with an increased risk of a dozen health conditions, including obesity, type 2 diabetes, heart disease and depression. Continue reading...
items.content: World’s largest scientific review warns consumption of UPFs poses seismic threat to global health and wellbeingUltra-processed food (UPF) is linked to harm in every major organ system of the human body and poses a seismic threat to global health, according to the world’s largest review.UPF is also rapidly displacing fresh food in the diets of children and adults on every continent, and is associated with an increased risk of a dozen health conditions, including obesity, type 2 diabetes, heart disease and depression. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Experts warn ultra-processed food poses a global health threat.
It increases the risk of chronic diseases.

The review is the world's largest scientific review.
Ultra-processed food is displacing fresh food globally.

clusters.title: Pam Zinkin obituary
clusters.neutral_headline: Obituary of Pamela Zinkin, paediatrician

items.title: Pam Zinkin obituary
items.standfirst: My mother, Pamela Zinkin, who has died aged 94, was a consultant paediatrician credited with saving the lives of children all over the world. She was also a lifelong campaigner for the NHS.In 1977, by then a single parent with two young sons, Pam moved to newly independent Mozambique to work as a senior paediatrician, then head of paediatrics, at Maputo central hospital. The country’s healthcare was in a precarious state, with 80% of its doctors having left after independence in 1975. Within five years, Pam and her team had reduced mortality among the 8,000 annual child admissions from 25% to 4%. Continue reading...
items.content: My mother, Pamela Zinkin, who has died aged 94, was a consultant paediatrician credited with saving the lives of children all over the world. She was also a lifelong campaigner for the NHS.In 1977, by then a single parent with two young sons, Pam moved to newly independent Mozambique to work as a senior paediatrician, then head of paediatrics, at Maputo central hospital. The country’s healthcare was in a precarious state, with 80% of its doctors having left after independence in 1975. Within five years, Pam and her team had reduced mortality among the 8,000 annual child admissions from 25% to 4%. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Pamela Zinkin was a consultant paediatrician.
She was credited with saving children's lives.
She was a lifelong campaigner for the NHS.
She worked in Mozambique after independence.
She reduced child mortality in a hospital.

clusters.title: I am the king of the common cold – and I can tell you how to avoid one | Adrian Chiles
clusters.neutral_headline: Adrian Chiles on avoiding the common cold

items.title: I am the king of the common cold – and I can tell you how to avoid one | Adrian Chiles
items.standfirst: No one suffers a cold like I do. Drops and brandy don’t touch the sides – but thanks to a friendly singer, I’ve learned a more extreme regime for countering the snufflesThis time last year, I was on a TV programme with three singers. There was a rapper of Ghanaian heritage, a big pop star, and a famous mezzo-soprano. It was deep midwinter. The night before, I’d been at an old friend’s 60th birthday, crammed into the function room of a pub somewhere in Surrey. It had been a good night, but now, just for something to say, I wondered how it was possible to avoid catching a cold when half the people at the party were players in a symphony of coughs, sneezes, snuffles and nose-blows. By the way, how come some people have nose-blows like trumpets, and others don’t? A question for another day.At mention of my night out, this trio of troubadours in the TV green room did two things. First, they shrunk away from me slightly. Second, they engaged in a feverishly enthusiastic discussion on how to avoid catching colds which, naturally enough given their line of work, was something of an obsession for them. I get that, but I have skin in this game too – I must avoid colds at all costs because the colds I get are worse than anyone else’s. I don’t have a medical certificate to confirm this, but I know it to be true. My colds last longer. My nose is more blocked, my throat is scratchier, my coughing fits are louder, barkier and apparently endless. My family, wise to the couple of quick throat-clearances which herald the coming storm, either kick me out of the room, or clear the room themselves. Back when I presented football on ITV, my poor colleagues in the studio gallery grew attuned to the warning signs. “Cans off!” the studio director would holler to his team, before I deafened them all, blowing the wiring in their headphones. Continue reading...
items.content: No one suffers a cold like I do. Drops and brandy don’t touch the sides – but thanks to a friendly singer, I’ve learned a more extreme regime for countering the snufflesThis time last year, I was on a TV programme with three singers. There was a rapper of Ghanaian heritage, a big pop star, and a famous mezzo-soprano. It was deep midwinter. The night before, I’d been at an old friend’s 60th birthday, crammed into the function room of a pub somewhere in Surrey. It had been a good night, but now, just for something to say, I wondered how it was possible to avoid catching a cold when half the people at the party were players in a symphony of coughs, sneezes, snuffles and nose-blows. By the way, how come some people have nose-blows like trumpets, and others don’t? A question for another day.At mention of my night out, this trio of troubadours in the TV green room did two things. First, they shrunk away from me slightly. Second, they engaged in a feverishly enthusiastic discussion on how to avoid catching colds which, naturally enough given their line of work, was something of an obsession for them. I get that, but I have skin in this game too – I must avoid colds at all costs because the colds I get are worse than anyone else’s. I don’t have a medical certificate to confirm this, but I know it to be true. My colds last longer. My nose is more blocked, my throat is scratchier, my coughing fits are louder, barkier and apparently endless. My family, wise to the couple of quick throat-clearances which herald the coming storm, either kick me out of the room, or clear the room themselves. Back when I presented football on ITV, my poor colleagues in the studio gallery grew attuned to the warning signs. “Cans off!” the studio director would holler to his team, before I deafened them all, blowing the wiring in their headphones. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Adrian Chiles discusses avoiding the common cold.
He describes his personal experience with colds.
He learned a regime from singers.
He finds his colds are worse than others.
He avoids colds due to his work.

clusters.title: Are resident doctors right to strike over pay? | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Resident doctors strike over pay

items.title: Are resident doctors right to strike over pay? | Letters
items.standfirst: Elizabeth Taylor fully backs industrial action and feels that doctors have been taken advantage of for decades; Dr Natasha de Vere would not consider strikingI totally support the resident doctors’ strike (Why the NHS doctors’ strikes look set to continue, 14 October). I am a retired consultant anaesthetist who worked in the NHS for 40 years. Throughout my career, I felt that I was totally underpaid for my work.As a junior doctor in the 1970s and up until my consultant appointment in 1991, I was paid a pittance for working excessive, unsafe hours – often 80 to 100 hours a week. Accommodation and catering were minimal. Overtime was paid at a much lower rate. Continue reading...
items.content: Elizabeth Taylor fully backs industrial action and feels that doctors have been taken advantage of for decades; Dr Natasha de Vere would not consider strikingI totally support the resident doctors’ strike (Why the NHS doctors’ strikes look set to continue, 14 October). I am a retired consultant anaesthetist who worked in the NHS for 40 years. Throughout my career, I felt that I was totally underpaid for my work.As a junior doctor in the 1970s and up until my consultant appointment in 1991, I was paid a pittance for working excessive, unsafe hours – often 80 to 100 hours a week. Accommodation and catering were minimal. Overtime was paid at a much lower rate. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Letters discuss resident doctors' strike.
One letter supports the industrial action.
Another letter would not consider striking.
The strike concerns pay and working conditions.
The letters offer different perspectives.

clusters.title: Labour is privatising the NHS in plain sight | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Labour is privatising the NHS in plain sight

items.title: Labour is privatising the NHS in plain sight | Letter
items.standfirst: Private appointments, tests and operations are a grave threat to the future of the health service, writes Margaret GreenwoodGaby Hinsliff is right to ask if the government’s reorganisation of the National Health Service will be the final nail in its coffin (Wes Streeting’s gamble with the NHS is greater than any play for Downing Street, 14 November). Such large‑scale redundancies are bound to create problems.There are other threats to the delivery of NHS services too. The privatisation of the NHS is happening in plain sight. Last month, the government proudly announced that “A total of 6.15 million appointments, tests and operations were delivered by independent providers for NHS patients this year”, an almost 500,000 increase on last year, which it says is “helping to cut waiting times [and] free up NHS capacity”. Continue reading...
items.content: Private appointments, tests and operations are a grave threat to the future of the health service, writes Margaret GreenwoodGaby Hinsliff is right to ask if the government’s reorganisation of the National Health Service will be the final nail in its coffin (Wes Streeting’s gamble with the NHS is greater than any play for Downing Street, 14 November). Such large‑scale redundancies are bound to create problems.There are other threats to the delivery of NHS services too. The privatisation of the NHS is happening in plain sight. Last month, the government proudly announced that “A total of 6.15 million appointments, tests and operations were delivered by independent providers for NHS patients this year”, an almost 500,000 increase on last year, which it says is “helping to cut waiting times [and] free up NHS capacity”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A letter discusses NHS privatization.
Private appointments are increasing.
The government announced increased use of private providers.
The letter argues this is a threat to the NHS.
The letter references a recent government announcement.

clusters.title: Huge staff cuts at WHO will leave world ‘less healthy and safe’, experts warn
clusters.neutral_headline: WHO to Cut Workforce Due to Funding Shortfall

items.title: Huge staff cuts at WHO will leave world ‘less healthy and safe’, experts warn
items.standfirst: Health organisation is to lose almost a quarter of its workforce in 2026, reducing its ability to help countries facing disease outbreaksThe loss of more than 2,000 jobs at the World Health Organization (WHO) “will leave the world less healthy and less safe”, experts have warned.The global health body said it expected to lose 2,371 posts – nearly a quarter of its workforce – by June 2026 as it deals with budget cuts after the US withdrawal from the organisation in January. At that point the WHO had 9,401 staff members. Continue reading...
items.content: Health organisation is to lose almost a quarter of its workforce in 2026, reducing its ability to help countries facing disease outbreaksThe loss of more than 2,000 jobs at the World Health Organization (WHO) “will leave the world less healthy and less safe”, experts have warned.The global health body said it expected to lose 2,371 posts – nearly a quarter of its workforce – by June 2026 as it deals with budget cuts after the US withdrawal from the organisation in January. At that point the WHO had 9,401 staff members. Continue reading...

items.title: WHO to lose nearly a quarter of its workforce – 2,000 jobs – due to US withdrawing funding
items.standfirst: Donald Trump’s administration withdrew from the World Health Organization in January, prompting the agency to scale back its workThe World Health Organization has said its workforce will shrink by nearly a quarter – or over 2,000 jobs – by the middle of next year as it seeks to implement reforms after its top donor, the United States, announced its departure.US President Donald Trump’s administration withdrew from the body upon taking office in January, prompting the agency to scale back its work and cut its management team by half. Continue reading...
items.content: Donald Trump’s administration withdrew from the World Health Organization in January, prompting the agency to scale back its workThe World Health Organization has said its workforce will shrink by nearly a quarter – or over 2,000 jobs – by the middle of next year as it seeks to implement reforms after its top donor, the United States, announced its departure.US President Donald Trump’s administration withdrew from the body upon taking office in January, prompting the agency to scale back its work and cut its management team by half. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The World Health Organization plans to cut nearly a quarter of its workforce by June 2026.
This reduction equates to a loss of 2,371 positions within the global health body.
The cuts are a result of budget constraints following US withdrawal in January.
The WHO had 9,401 staff members before the planned workforce reduction.
Experts warn these cuts will make the world less healthy and safe.

clusters.title: The FDA has warned against this ‘natural remedy’ for joint pain. San Francisco immigrants still trust it
clusters.neutral_headline: FDA Warns Against Joint Pain Remedy, San Francisco Latinos Still Trust It

items.title: The FDA has warned against this ‘natural remedy’ for joint pain. San Francisco immigrants still trust it
items.standfirst: In San Francisco, doctors say, a growing number of Latinos who work physically demanding jobs have turned to supplements that promise relief for joint and bone pain. FDA warnings are not filtering throughThis story was co-published with El Tecolote, a bilingual community newsroom that serves Latinx communities who live or work in San Francisco.When Gloria Caballero, 52, started experiencing knee pain four years ago, her sister in Los Angeles suggested a natural remedy that a co-worker had sworn by: a supplement called Artri Ajo King. Following her advice, Caballero started buying the yellow-and-blue pills in Los Angeles and bringing them up to her home in San Francisco, where she started taking them twice a day, every day. Continue reading...

FDA warnings are not filtering throughThis story was co-published with El Tecolote, a bilingual community newsroom that serves Latinx communities who live or work in San Francisco.When Gloria Caballero, 52, started experiencing knee pain four years ago, her sister in Los Angeles suggested a natural remedy that a co-worker had sworn by: a supplement called Artri Ajo King. Following her advice, Caballero started buying the yellow-and-blue pills in Los Angeles and bringing them up to her home in San Francisco, where she started taking them twice a day, every day. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Some Latinos in San Francisco use supplements for joint and bone pain relief.
The FDA has issued warnings about a "natural remedy" called Artri Ajo King.
Gloria Caballero, 52, started taking Artri Ajo King for knee pain.
She buys the supplement in Los Angeles and takes it daily in San Francisco.
The story was co-published with a bilingual community newsroom.

clusters.title: I look at a stranger and see a friend. Am I a super-recognizer?
clusters.neutral_headline: Recognizing Strangers: A Sign of Super-Recognition?

items.title: I look at a stranger and see a friend. Am I a super-recognizer?
items.standfirst: I once even thought I had seen my late grandmother. Can science explain my overfamiliarity with strange faces?When I was in my mid-20s, I spotted my grandma through the window of a coffee shop. I was dumbstruck – she had passed away the year before. I stared for a moment, then reminded myself it couldn’t be her.I’d had similar experiences all my life. Every now and then, I “recognized” someone I didn’t know. Sometimes I could quickly pinpoint who the stranger reminded me of – like my grandma. Other times, a face simply had a vague familiarity I couldn’t place. Continue reading...
items.content: I once even thought I had seen my late grandmother. Can science explain my overfamiliarity with strange faces?When I was in my mid-20s, I spotted my grandma through the window of a coffee shop. I was dumbstruck – she had passed away the year before. I stared for a moment, then reminded myself it couldn’t be her.I’d had similar experiences all my life. Every now and then, I “recognized” someone I didn’t know. Sometimes I could quickly pinpoint who the stranger reminded me of – like my grandma. Other times, a face simply had a vague familiarity I couldn’t place. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author often feels a sense of familiarity with unfamiliar faces.
She once thought she saw her deceased grandmother in a coffee shop.
These experiences have occurred throughout her life, with varying degrees of recognition.
Sometimes, she can identify the person the stranger reminds her of.
Other times, the familiarity is vague and unidentifiable.

clusters.title: Disease fears as Argentina child vaccination rates hit historic lows
clusters.neutral_headline: Argentina's Child Vaccination Rates Hit Historic Lows

items.title: Disease fears as Argentina child vaccination rates hit historic lows
items.standfirst: Sharp drop since 2024 in country regarded as a Latin American leader in childhood and adolescent immunisationArgentina’s childhood and adolescent vaccination rates have collapsed to historic lows, according to a new analysis, prompting warnings that once-eliminated diseases may resurge.The study of health ministry data by the Argentinian Paediatric Society (SAP) found that fewer than half of children aged five and six received several of their essential doses in 2024. All vaccine rates analysed were below the 95% level needed to reach herd immunity. Continue reading...
items.content: Sharp drop since 2024 in country regarded as a Latin American leader in childhood and adolescent immunisationArgentina’s childhood and adolescent vaccination rates have collapsed to historic lows, according to a new analysis, prompting warnings that once-eliminated diseases may resurge.The study of health ministry data by the Argentinian Paediatric Society (SAP) found that fewer than half of children aged five and six received several of their essential doses in 2024. All vaccine rates analysed were below the 95% level needed to reach herd immunity. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Argentina's childhood vaccination rates have dropped to historic lows.
The Argentinian Paediatric Society analyzed health ministry data.
Fewer than half of children aged five and six received essential doses in 2024.
All analyzed vaccine rates were below the 95% herd immunity level.
Experts warn of potential resurgence of previously eliminated diseases.

The trial suggests it could shorten treatment time by months.
An estimated 10.7 million people fell ill with TB last year.
Approximately 1.23 million deaths were attributed to TB globally.

clusters.title: Wednesday briefing: Why strangulation during sex has become so common among teenagers
clusters.neutral_headline: Why Strangulation During Sex Has Become Common Among Teenagers

items.title: Wednesday briefing: Why strangulation during sex has become so common among teenagers
items.standfirst: In today’s newsletter: Despite the risks, many young people now see choking during intimacy as acceptable or even expected, which experts put down to the proliferation of increasingly violent online pornography Good morning. Yesterday, I was shocked to read that nearly half of sexually active under-18s have either been strangled or strangled someone during sex.“Choking”, as it is known, has become normalised in young people’s sexual habits. A study by the Institute for Addressing Strangulation, part of the Faculty of Forensic and Legal Medicine of the Royal College of Physicians, published on Tuesday, found that 43% of under-18s had experienced the practice, despite much evidence of the dangers it can cause.Politics | Nigel Farage is facing fresh claims of racism and antisemitism while he was at school, with a Bafta-winning director among those making accusations against him. The Reform UK leader denies the allegations.Technology | A key piece of the internet’s usually hidden infrastructure suffered a global outage on Tuesday. Cloudflare, whose services include defending millions of websites against malicious attacks, experienced an unidentified problem that meant internet users could not access some websites.Health | The NHS has failed to cut waiting times as promised in its recovery plan despite billions of pounds in investment, the public accounts committee has warned.Home Office | Shabana Mahmood is facing demands for compassion and clarity after it emerged that only a “few hundred” asylum seekers would initially be permitted to come to the UK under three new schemes for refugees.Espionage | MI5 has issued an espionage alert to MPs and peers warning that two people linked to the Chinese intelligence service are actively seeking to recruit parliamentarians through LinkedIn. Continue reading...
items.content: In today’s newsletter: Despite the risks, many young people now see choking during intimacy as acceptable or even expected, which experts put down to the proliferation of increasingly violent online pornography Good morning. Yesterday, I was shocked to read that nearly half of sexually active under-18s have either been strangled or strangled someone during sex.“Choking”, as it is known, has become normalised in young people’s sexual habits. A study by the Institute for Addressing Strangulation, part of the Faculty of Forensic and Legal Medicine of the Royal College of Physicians, published on Tuesday, found that 43% of under-18s had experienced the practice, despite much evidence of the dangers it can cause.Politics | Nigel Farage is facing fresh claims of racism and antisemitism while he was at school, with a Bafta-winning director among those making accusations against him. The Reform UK leader denies the allegations.Technology | A key piece of the internet’s usually hidden infrastructure suffered a global outage on Tuesday. Cloudflare, whose services include defending millions of websites against malicious attacks, experienced an unidentified problem that meant internet users could not access some websites.Health | The NHS has failed to cut waiting times as promised in its recovery plan despite billions of pounds in investment, the public accounts committee has warned.Home Office | Shabana Mahmood is facing demands for compassion and clarity after it emerged that only a “few hundred” asylum seekers would initially be permitted to come to the UK under three new schemes for refugees.Espionage | MI5 has issued an espionage alert to MPs and peers warning that two people linked to the Chinese intelligence service are actively seeking to recruit parliamentarians through LinkedIn. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A study found 43% of under-18s have experienced strangulation during sex.
Experts attribute this to the normalization of choking in young people's sexual habits.
The Institute for Addressing Strangulation conducted the study.
The study is part of the Faculty of Forensic and Legal Medicine of the Royal College of Physicians.
The article also includes unrelated news briefs on politics, technology, health, and espionage.

clusters.title: Australia’s peak health body for men distances itself from conservative group’s International Men’s Day campaign
clusters.neutral_headline: Australia's Health Body Distances Itself From Conservative Group

items.title: Australia’s peak health body for men distances itself from conservative group’s International Men’s Day campaign
items.standfirst: Australian Men’s Health Forum says it is not affiliated with Dads4Kids group espousing anti-feminist, anti-LGBTQI+ viewsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastA group that espouses anti-feminist and anti-LGBTQ+ sentiments is running an International Men’s Day (IMD) campaign that is similar to a government-funded campaign aimed at “supporting men and boys”.The Australian Men’s Health Forum (AMHF) is the government-funded peak body for men’s mental and physical health and has coordinated IMD, an annual event on 19 November, since 2017. This year’s theme is “supporting men and boys”. Continue reading...
items.content: Australian Men’s Health Forum says it is not affiliated with Dads4Kids group espousing anti-feminist, anti-LGBTQI+ viewsFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastA group that espouses anti-feminist and anti-LGBTQ+ sentiments is running an International Men’s Day (IMD) campaign that is similar to a government-funded campaign aimed at “supporting men and boys”.The Australian Men’s Health Forum (AMHF) is the government-funded peak body for men’s mental and physical health and has coordinated IMD, an annual event on 19 November, since 2017. This year’s theme is “supporting men and boys”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Australian Men's Health Forum is not affiliated with Dads4Kids.
Dads4Kids promotes anti-feminist and anti-LGBTQI+ views.
The AMHF is the government-funded peak body for men's health.
The AMHF coordinates International Men's Day (IMD) annually.
This year's IMD theme is "supporting men and boys".

clusters.title: First kiss dates back 21 million years, say scientists
clusters.neutral_headline: First kiss dates back 21 million years, say scientists

items.title: First kiss dates back 21 million years, say scientists
items.standfirst: A new study looks at how the mouth-on-mouth smooch came into being, and concludes that Neanderthals also kissed.
items.content: A new study looks at how the mouth-on-mouth smooch came into being, and concludes that Neanderthals also kissed.

ai_summary: A new study examines the origins of mouth-to-mouth kissing.
The study concludes that Neanderthals also engaged in kissing.
The research suggests kissing dates back 21 million years.
The study explores the evolution of this behavior.
The article focuses on the scientific findings about kissing.

clusters.title: Coroners’ advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales routinely ignored, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Coroners’ advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales routinely ignored, study finds

items.title: Coroners’ advice on maternal deaths in England and Wales routinely ignored, study finds
items.standfirst: Nearly two-thirds of ‘prevention of future deaths’ reports by coroners are not acted upon, say researchers at King’s College LondonThe advice given by coroners in England and Wales to help prevent maternal deaths is not being acted upon, research suggests.Academics at King’s College London looked at prevention of future deaths (PFD) reports issued by coroners in cases of pregnant women and new mothers who died between 2013 and 2023. They found these reports were not being “systematically used nationally”. Continue reading...
items.content: Nearly two-thirds of ‘prevention of future deaths’ reports by coroners are not acted upon, say researchers at King’s College LondonThe advice given by coroners in England and Wales to help prevent maternal deaths is not being acted upon, research suggests.Academics at King’s College London looked at prevention of future deaths (PFD) reports issued by coroners in cases of pregnant women and new mothers who died between 2013 and 2023. They found these reports were not being “systematically used nationally”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Research indicates coroners' advice on maternal deaths is often ignored.
Academics at King's College London conducted the study.
They examined "prevention of future deaths" reports.
The reports were issued by coroners between 2013 and 2023.
Nearly two-thirds of the reports are not acted upon.

clusters.title: NHS failing to cut waiting times as promised in recovery plan, report warns
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS failing to cut waiting times as promised in recovery plan, report warns

items.title: NHS failing to cut waiting times as promised in recovery plan, report warns
items.standfirst: Public accounts committee finds Labour’s progress ‘appears to have stalled’ despite billions of pounds in investmentThe NHS has failed to cut waiting times as promised in its recovery plan despite billions of pounds in investment, the public accounts committee (PAC) has warned.The influential parliamentary committee’s verdict raises serious doubts over whether Labour can fulfil its key pledge to voters to “fix the NHS” by ensuring that patients can once again get hospital care within 18 weeks by 2029.Key NHS targets to improve access to both planned care and diagnostic tests by last spring “were missed”.NHS England had spent £3.24bn setting up community diagnostic centres and surgical hubs but had not achieved the aim of reducing delays.In July, 192,000 people had been waiting at least a year for care, despite a pledge to eradicate that practice altogether by March 2025.22% of patients were having to wait more than six weeks for a diagnostic test, even though that was due to be cut to 5% by March. Continue reading...
items.content: Public accounts committee finds Labour’s progress ‘appears to have stalled’ despite billions of pounds in investmentThe NHS has failed to cut waiting times as promised in its recovery plan despite billions of pounds in investment, the public accounts committee (PAC) has warned.The influential parliamentary committee’s verdict raises serious doubts over whether Labour can fulfil its key pledge to voters to “fix the NHS” by ensuring that patients can once again get hospital care within 18 weeks by 2029.Key NHS targets to improve access to both planned care and diagnostic tests by last spring “were missed”.NHS England had spent £3.24bn setting up community diagnostic centres and surgical hubs but had not achieved the aim of reducing delays.In July, 192,000 people had been waiting at least a year for care, despite a pledge to eradicate that practice altogether by March 2025.22% of patients were having to wait more than six weeks for a diagnostic test, even though that was due to be cut to 5% by March. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The NHS has failed to reduce waiting times as promised.
The Public Accounts Committee issued the warning.
The committee found progress had stalled despite investment.
Key NHS targets to improve access were missed.
The NHS had spent billions on diagnostic centers and hubs.

clusters.title: Brazil creates new Indigenous territories during protest-hit COP30
clusters.neutral_headline: Brazil creates new Indigenous territories during protest-hit COP30

items.title: Brazil creates new Indigenous territories during protest-hit COP30
items.standfirst: President Lula's government recognises 10 new Indigenous lands in an effort to protect their culture and environment.
items.content: President Lula's government recognises 10 new Indigenous lands in an effort to protect their culture and environment.

ai_summary: President Lula's government recognized ten new Indigenous lands.
The action aims to protect Indigenous culture and environment.
The announcement occurred during the COP30 climate summit.
The summit was marked by protests.
The government's action is related to environmental protection.
